awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: Charge-Recycling based Computing Paradigm for Wirelessly Powered Internet-of-Things
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary objective of this research is to develop a new computing paradigm for wirelessly powered Internet-of-things (IoT) based devices and enhance their computational capabilities by more than an order of magnitude. The proposed research brings new opportunities to emerging applications such as computational RFIDs (Radio Frequency Identifiers), bio-implantable devices, and structural/environmental monitoring. The results of this research will contribute to the development of smarter IoT devices that are beyond the boundaries of traditional cyber-physical systems. Thus, significant new opportunities are expected in healthcare, energy, structural and environmental monitoring with substantial benefits to science, industry, and society at large. The PIs will promote outreach activities with emphasis on high school students and underrepresented groups. Undergraduate involvement will be encouraged through not only traditional means, but also through involvement of the PIs in professional societies and REU opportunities. 

One of the significant barriers that slows down the global scalability of IoT devices is the energy cost. Despite a variety of already existing techniques for energy harvesting methods, the computing capability of most of the IoT devices is limited by the available power. This research embodies a novel vision on developing an efficient computing method and corresponding IoT hardware architecture tailored for wireless energy harvesting. Specifically, the existing charge-recycling theory is leveraged in a unique way and the harvested AC signal is used to directly power the IoT device. Remarkable benefits are expected from this approach, e.g., i) the power loss due to rectification and regulation are eliminated, ii) the computational unit within the IoT device operates an order of magnitude more efficiently since the electrical charge is recycled rather than dissipated to ground. This unprecedented increase in energy efficiency enhances the on-site IoT device intelligence, thereby allowing for local decision making mechanisms.

por.por_cntn:
Energy autonomy is a primary obstacle facing future Internet-of-things (IoT). Among various energy scavenging techniques, wireless energy harvesting has become an attractive method to power IoT based devices. Due to the scarcity of available wireless power (either from ambient environment or from dedicated sources such as a reader), these IoT devices (such as wireless sensor nodes, radio frequency tags, implantable devices) typically do not have sufficient computational capability. The primary objective of this research has been to significantly enhance the computational capability of wirelessly-powered devices by leveraging charge-recycling/adiabatic logic. The use of charge-recycling logic is motivated by the fact that the wirelessly harvested signal is in the form of an alternating current (AC) signal. Such a signal can potentially be directly used by charge-recycling logic, therefore eliminating the need for lossy rectification. Furthermore, charge-recycling logic dissipates significantly less power than conventional approaches due to adiabatic charging, particularly in the low-to-mid megahertz frequency range. A conceptual comparison of the conventional approach with the proposed technique is provided in Figure 1. The proposed technique achieves more than an order of magnitude reduction in power consumption and therefore significantly enhances on-site device intelligence of IoT devices.

Existing charge-recycling logic families cannot be directly used for wirelessly-powered devices due to bipolar harvested signal and requirement to provide a direct current (DC) based bias voltage to some of the transistors. These limitations were mitigated in this research by developing efficient specialized circuits such as peak detector, phase shifter and signal shaper. Multiple case studies were developed to evaluate the overall methodology.  A near-field wireless link was designed with application to brain implantable devices and an AC-powered 8-bit arithmetic logic unit (ALU) was developed. Power consumption was reduced by 16X. Impact of circuit size and voltage scaling on power consumption and robustness of the circuit was also investigated. In another case study, an AC-powered lightweight encryption core was designed using two different charge-recycling logic families. Up to 27X improvement in encryption efficiency was demonstrated. A test chip was also fabricated in 65 nm CMOS technology, as shown in Figure 2. In addition to improvement in efficiency, the benefits of charge-recycling operation in hardware security were also explored. A novel charge-recycling logic family with significantly higher side-channel resistance was developed for wirelessly-powered devices. To summarize, the encouraging characteristics of charge-recycling/adiabatic circuits were demonstrated for wirelessly powered IoT devices. Multiple future research directions were also outlined.

Significant contributions have been made to education and future workforce development as part of this research. Two PhD students graduated and started working in leading semiconductor companies. Multiple undergraduate students were also involved via senior design projects or independent research. Three journal papers and ten conference papers were published. One patent application was granted, and another patent application is pending. Several special sessions were organized by the PIs in leading IEEE/ACM conferences to further disseminate the results obtained in this research. The PIs also participated in various departmental outreach activities with participation from underrepresented students.
